bibl.title: Letter from Aristides Agramonte to Jefferson Randolph Kean, August 4, 1911

div1.p: Agramonte informs Kean of Finlay's declining health. [Courtesy of the National Archives and Records Administration]

div1.head: Letter from Aristides Agramonte to Jefferson Randolph Kean, August 4, 1911
div1.opener:
DR. ARISTIDES AGRAMONTE
CALLE K, ENTRE 15 Y 17
VEDADO, HABANA.
--
Havana, Aug. 4th, 1911.
Lt. Colonel J. R. Kean, U. S. Army,
Washington, D. C.
My dear Col. Kean:
div1.p:
Have just returned from abroad and find your letter of
April 27th as well as copies of the compilations of the writings of the memobers of
the Yellow Fever Commission. I shall distribute them in due time.

Am sorry to say that I find Dr. Finlay declining quite rapidly and his mental
condition is such as to preclude his taking interest in anything of a serious character.
It is very sad to see his gradual descent and physical deterioration.

Dr. Guitéras is at present in New York looking after the cholera question there
and sanitary matters here are very active from a political standpoint. The Commission
of Infectious Diseases has been deprived of its fees as well as several of the Members
of the Superior, (now National,) Health Board so that unless some action be taken at
the next Legislature, in November, we are all going to resign. I hope matters will be
straightened out to avoid this step which will certainly be in detriment of the admi-
nistration, but, as you know, the work of the Commission, at least, is one that entails
an actual expenditure of time and labour and therefore cannot be carried out gratis
for an indefinite period of time.

I would have liked to have seen some of my own publications appearing in the printed
matter you sent me, but the thing cannot be arranged now so that the least said about
it the better. Thank you very much for sending the copies and with best regards I
remain.
